questions.question_text:
A security analyst's daily review of system logs and SIEM showed fluctuating patterns of latency. During the analysis, the analyst discovered recent attempts of intrusion related to malware that overwrites the MBR. The facilities manager informed the analyst that a nearby construction project damaged the primary power lines, impacting the analyst's support systems. The electric company has temporarily restored power, but the area may experience temporary outages.
Which of the following issues the analyst focus on to continue operations?

discussion.content:
(B) Conducting backups — The electric company has temporarily restored power, but the area may experience temporary outages so the backup might not complete as a result.

(C) Virus scanning — Same as (B)

(D) Additional log analysis — Daily review of the system log and SIEM showed fluctuating patterns of latency as a result of a nearby construction project damaging the primary power lines. This means carrying out further investigation could result in the same issue as well as the problem faced in (B)

This is why I'm going with Updating the ACL (A) since the analyst only discovered attempts not attack. Updating the ACL can be done quicker than other options and will block further attempts from the malware.

Should B.
In the question, it clearly says the following points.
- daily review of system logs 
- the analyst discovered recent attempts of intrusion-related to malware 
- impacting the analyst’s support systems
- the area may experience temporary outages
then question ask "focus on to continue operations" 

When coming to continue operation. 
A - Not an answer for this outage issue
B - Suitable, Analyst should ready to move new backups of taking logs and prepare for new system in the mean time.
C - This is remediation/prevention stage of incident, but continue operation may distrupt if we do not have any backup plan
D - After making the backup should go with Additional log anlaysis related on incident.

I personally think it's D, but I'm not 100% certain.

A. Not conduction an in-depth investigation.
B. Backups should be taken automatically, and not initiated when there is "possible malware on a system". In addition, I would advise against taking backups from systems while there may be power outages.
C. Potentially, yeah, I guess, but it's not good enough imho.
D. I would focus on this one as an analyst. Sure the power might go out right in the middle of my investigation, but I'd just pick up from where I left off once the power comes back on.

I'm not sure what "the analysts support systems" are a reference to though. Their SIEM? The hosts themselves? The machine the analyst is working on? No clue... .
should this not be B to ensure continuing operations?

comments.content:
The full sentence is recent attempts of intrusion RELATED to malware. This would mean that the system has already been infected with malware, and that the malware is attempting to overwrite the MBR. 
Run a virus scan to remove the malware to prevent further attempts at overwriting the MBR. C is correct.

It says "attempts", doesn't say any of them were successful. Assuming that means the malware hasn't made it internally, the correct answer would be B. This would prepare you if the malware did in fact make it into the network. I would hope that other controls are considered as well to keep the malware out.

The security analyst can't do anything with regards to the temporary power outages. That is for the facilities/building team' problem to solve since they should have invested on generator sets for this kind of problems. But in this case, there is a potential malware in the network, so it should be his focus.

choices.D: The company has been breached, and customer PII is being exfiltrated to the CDN.
choices.B: The CDN provider has misclassified the network traffic as hostile.
choices.A: The CDN provider has mistakenly performed a GeoIP mapping to the company.
choices.C: A vulnerability scan has tuned to exclude web assets hosted by the CDN.

discussion.content: I cant see this being D. The company is hosting static content, which is traditionally, images, font files, large non changing data. The goal is faster web page loading times = better user experience. I can only imagine B.

Any ideas on this one? I'm thinking either B or C.

A. The CDN provider has mistakenly performed a GeoIP mapping to the company. - Not sure if this is really related.
B. The CDN provider has misclassified the network traffic as hostile. - Possible that the attack traffic is just a false positive.
C. A vulnerability scan has tuned to exclude web assets hosted by the CDN. = if they have excluded the web assets hosted by the CDN, then there shouldn't by any attack traffic being reported. Or is this worded incorrectly, and should be tuned to include?
D. The company has been breached, and customer PII is being exfiltrated to the CDN. - If PII is being exfiltrated, then the CDN shouldn't be seeing it as attack traffic.

comments.content: I don't know anything about this. The only thing I can come up with is that an incorrect configuration could spell pure chaos. So my guess is it's either A or B. I don't know what A means, so I'm picking B. And I'm far from sure of that one either.
If there's one thing I know for sure, it's that none of the answers are ever misclassified or false positives. I guess we'll have to give the CDN provider the benefit of the doubt here

questions.question_text:
A company has a popular shopping cart website hosted geographically diverse locations. The company has started hosting static content on a content delivery network (CDN) to improve performance. The CDN provider has reported the company is occasionally sending attack traffic to other CDN-hosted targets.
Which of the following has MOST likely occurred?

choices.D: Public information officer, human resources, audit, customer service
choices.B: Chief Information Officer (CIO), Chief Executive Officer, board of directors, stockholders
choices.C: IT, human resources, security administrator, finance
choices.A: Human resources, legal, public relations, management

questions.question_text: In the development stage of the incident response policy, the security analyst needs to determine the stakeholders for the policy. Who of the following would be the policy stakeholders?

comments.content: pretty sure is "A", my reference NIST 800 SP 61r2.
They are part of incident response, but you need the company board members to be involved in making policy. Since A doesn't include board members, B should be the right answer

discussion.content: The question is about "policy" not "response! If it was "response - yes you are right! But it is POLICY! Who makes POLICY!

I initially went with A but I reread the question.
I think B is the answer. B includs A, but A dosen't include B.

comments.content: Would stockholders have anything to do with the incident response policy? If no, then can't be B

questions.question_text: The help desk has reported that users are reusing previous passwords when prompted to change them. Which of the following would be the MOST appropriate control for the security analyst to configure to prevent password reuse? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: C is good and I would go with E since it caters to both linux and windows hosts

comments.content:
C. One of the best answer that we have.
D. Accounts enrolled in PAM sometimes have automated password change scheduled so as to eliminate reuse of passwords. 
E. SSO can decrease password reuse. But it can't prevent them.

A & C are suitable answers. 
A - mandatory access control (MAC) approach to security. In a MAC system,
administrators set all security permissions, and end users cannot modify
those permissions
all other options beside A and C arent accurate

I can see that argument.. But from what I'm reading about PAM, it is used for single sign on. With that in mind I think C & E is the best answer. Single sign on is recommended to decrease password reuse.

choices.D: Implement scripts to automate the configuration of PAM on Linux hosts.
choices.A: Implement mandatory access control on all workstations.
choices.E: Deploy a single-sing-on solution for both Windows and Linux hosts.
choices.B: Implement role-based access control within directory services.
choices.C: Deploy Group Policy Objects to domain resources.
Customers are logging off the kiosk and guessing the root account password.
choices.D: Customers are escaping the application shell and gaining root-level access.
choices.B: The kiosk user account has execute permissions on the server data files.
choices.A: Data on the server is not encrypted, allowing users to change the pricing data.

discussion.content:
A. This has nothing to do with file permissions
B. execute permissions has nothing to do with accessing pricing data. It's for executing executables
C. Logs do not mention attempts at brute force attacks
D. Operating system is hardened, but doesn't mention how secure the application shell is. D is the most likely answer here

I'm going with C or D:
A - encryption doesn't change the write permissions 
B - Its confirmed in the question that the Kiosk doesn't have write permissions 
C - Although possible i can't imagine this is really likely
D - Much like C i can't think of common scenarios for this but could be possible
I think it would be D as the kiosk user is only suppose to run on the Application first opened on the Kiosk and other changes have been made by the root user.
Can anyone explain this? I'm thinking of A

comments.content: Very vague question... as always... but escaping from "kiosk" applications is a common thing to do in the hacker community: https://book.hacktricks.xyz/physical-attacks/escaping-from-gui-applications

questions.question_text:
A business recently installed a kiosk that is running on a hardened operating system as a restricted user. The kiosk user application is the only application that is allowed to run. A security analyst gets a report that pricing data is being modified on the server, and management wants to know how this is happening. After reviewing the logs, the analyst discovers the root account from the kiosk is accessing the files. After validating the permissions on the server, the analyst confirms the permissions from the kiosk do not allow to write to the server data.
Which of the following is the MOST likely reason for the pricing data modifications on the server?
